initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==

The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

Out of these initial outreaches Darko Culjak became the senior minister and established the church (then called "Kiev Christian Life Centre") officially on [[October 4]], [[1992]]. Darko Culjak lead the church, raised up a ministry team from among the new converts and oversaw the new church until its indigenous leaders could take over the work and come under the guidance and governance of Hillsong Church in Sydney, Australia. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], Darko turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. After their appointment, Pastor Darko left and spent some rest time in the USA until he returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church. 
 
 As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. <ref>[http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp YC Alberta 2006: TELL THE WORLD]</ref>
llm_output:
The change made is a rephrasing of the term "theatre" to "movie theatre" in the context of describing the location where the church began its outreach in Kiev.

Not Weaponised. The change is a simple clarification of the type of venue without introducing any politically charged language or narratives related to cultural heritage.

initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Charismatic and Pentecostal Christianity]]
[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Charismatic and Pentecostal Christianity]]
[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]

As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===

===Bible college===

The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

@@ -14,7 +14,7 @@
 '''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].
 
 ==History==
-In September 1992, an outreach began in the [[October Palace, Kiev|October Palace]] in Kiev with team members from Hills Christian Life Centre (now known as Hillsong Church).  Australian worship leader David Evans, USA pastor Mike Berry and former Hillsong youth pastor Darko Culjak as a part of Hillsong's Nation Builders mission outreach officially began the church in a 700 seat movie theatre in downtown Kiev. But none of this would have been possible without the assistance of [[Pat Robertson]]'s [[CBN]] and their television ministry into the [[former Soviet Union]] under Steve Webber. Through their assistance hundreds of young people committed their lives to Christ. Out of these initial outreaches Darko Culjak became the senior minister and established the church (then called "Kiev Christian Life Centre") officially on October 4, 1992. Darko Culjak lead the church, raised up a ministry team from among the new converts and oversaw the new church until its locally educated leaders could take over the work and come under the guidance and governance of Hillsong Church in Sydney, Australia. On June 1, 1997, Darko turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. After their appointment, Pastor Darko left and spent some rest time in the USA until he returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

But none of this would have been possible without the assistance of [[Pat Robertson]]'s [[CBN]] and their television ministry into the [[former Soviet Union]] under Steve Webber. Through their assistance hundreds of young people committed their lives to Christ. Out of these initial outreaches Darko Culjak became the senior minister and established the church (then called "Kiev Christian Life Centre") officially on October 4, 1992. Darko Culjak lead the church, raised up a ministry team from among the new converts and oversaw the new church until Kiev's locally educated leaders could take over the work and come under the guidance and governance of Hillsong Church in Sydney, Australia. On June 1, 1997, Darko turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. After their appointment, Pastor Darko left and spent some rest time in the USA until he returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church. 
 
 As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. <ref>[http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp YC Alberta 2006: TELL THE WORLD]</ref>

 In September 1992, an outreach began in the [[October Palace, Kiev|October Palace]] in Kiev with team members from Hills Christian Life Centre (now known as Hillsong Church).  Australian worship leader David Evans, USA pastor Mike Berry and former Hillsong youth pastor Darko Culjak as a part of Hillsong's Nation Builders mission outreach officially began the church in a 700 seat movie theatre in downtown Kiev. But none of this would have been possible without the assistance of [[Pat Robertson]]'s [[CBN]] and their television ministry into the [[former Soviet Union]] under Steve Webber. Through their assistance hundreds of young people committed their lives to Christ. Out of these initial outreaches Darko Culjak became the senior minister and established the church (then called "Kiev Christian Life Centre") officially on October 4, 1992. Darko Culjak lead the church, raised up a ministry team from among the new converts and oversaw the new church until Kiev's locally educated leaders could take over the work and come under the guidance and governance of Hillsong Church in Sydney, Australia. On June 1, 1997, Darko turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. After their appointment, Pastor Darko left and spent some rest time in the USA until he returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church. 
 
 As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. <ref>[http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp YC Alberta 2006: TELL THE WORLD]</ref>
+

+churches, synagogues and Islamic foundations to spread the message of universal peace,
+brotherhood, security and prosperity for all mankind in these troubled times.
+
+	Our LORD Almighty has praised Christians in the Holy Quranic Verses 3:55,
+5:82,57:27,28, except Quranic Verses 5:14,15,16 & 57,9:31. As per Quranic Verses 
+4:59 and 83, it is our duty to spread the message of universal peace and human brotherhood.
+Please download from web site WWW.GOLDENDUAS.COM  prayers from Holy Quran regarding the same. The message may be circulated to all concerned through government websites, media publications in all languages and through all mediums of communication as per  Quranic Verses 2:2,10:57,17:11,16,28:59, 39:55,57,13:37&65:8. 
+Otherwise it will amount to refusal to follow our Lord's Order, guidance and 
+direction as per Quranic Verses 6:26.
+
+With kind regards
+
+ U.IBRAHIM ALI
 
 ==Ministries==
 Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]

initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Charismatic and Pentecostal Christianity]]
[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

 Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Church in Sydney, and recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.
 
-The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in Autumn 2007.
+There have been close to 20 albumn recordings.
 
 ==Venues==
 Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship centre, renting an exhibition marquee in industrial outskirts of Kiev for its services. It does own two offices, purchased in 2002 and 2007 on credit with instalments from both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Charismatic and Pentecostal Christianity]]
[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Charismatic and Pentecostal Christianity]]
[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

Removed a section of text that included a message from U. Ibrahim Ali regarding interfaith relations and the promotion of peace through Quranic verses.

Not Weaponised – The removed content does not contain any language or narratives that could be interpreted as weaponising cultural heritage. It appears to be a benign interfaith message promoting peace and brotherhood.

initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Charismatic and Pentecostal Christianity]]
[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

However, according to "pastor" Yevgeny Kasevich, he would not "go to the extremes" when teaching prosperity believing that "we are blessed (only) to be a blessing to others".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.invictory.org/issue10443.html|title=Web Conference with Yevgeny and Vera Kasevich |publisher=news.invictory.org|accessdate=2007-10-14|date=2007-02-23}} (in Russian)</ref>

initial_version:
'''Hillsong Church Kiev''' (formerly '''Kiev Christian Life Centre''') is the [[Kiev]]-based offshoot of [[Hillsong Church]] in [[Sydney]], [[Australia]].

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

==History==
The church was started on [[October 4]], [[1992]] by a team from Hillsong Australia, leaving Pastor Darko Culjak to oversee the new church. On [[June 1]], [[1997]], he turned the church over to a Ukrainian couple - Yevgeny ([[Zhenya Kasevich|Zhenya]]) and [[Vera Kasevich]], who had been with the church since the day it was planted and have thus become the new Senior Pastors of the church. Pastor Darko returned to Australia to pastor the Newcastle City Church.

As of 2007, the church holds 6 to 7 services each weekend (the number changes from season to season) with a combined attendance of around 3000. Pastors Zhenya and Vera have since gained an international recognition and are being invited to speak at various churches and Christian conferences around the globe. [http://www.ycgeneration.com/yc2006/guests_zk.asp]

==Ministries==
Hillsong Kiev tries to align its ministries structure with that of the mother church in Sydney. There are 3-part courses for new believers, named "Discovery". The church reflects the belief that small "connect groups" are essential for the fellowship spirit within the church, especially as it gets larger. Connect groups and sometimes special services are held for people of various ages and with various interests, such as youth, or "people over 40", or those who like fishing or computers. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/ministries/index.html] Hillsong Kiev is characterized by a high level of involvement of its members in serving at the church and is believed by observers to have the best level of the organization of ministry among all Protestant churches in Europe. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571]
[[Image:Hillsongkievconference2006.jpg|thumb|Praise and worship during the opening night of Hillsong Conference in Kiev, 2006]]
===Conferences===
As both [[Hillsong Church|Hillsong Australia]] and [[Hillsong London]], Hillsong Kiev holds 3 yearly conferences: the Hillsong Conference, the Colour Your World conference for women, and a men's conference. The Hillsong Conference, meant to equip other churches with both Biblical teaching and practical advice on organizing the life of a church, gathered about 3000 delegates from more than 250 churches from 12 countries, mainly representing the former Soviet bloc, in 2006.

===Social work===
Hillsong Kiev is making considerable efforts to be a servant to the community by helping orphanages in Kiev and Kiev area, supporting sick people in hospitals treating cancer, reaching out to homeless children and inmates in correctional centers.[http://www.hillsong.com.ua/transforminglives/index.php?r=TransformingLives]

===Bible college===
The church has a Bible college offering a 1- to 3-year studies plan, meant mainly for those who wish to serve in the church, although participation in ministry at the "helps" level is not contingent on a person's completing a study course. Students from Protestant churches of other cities of Ukraine as well as other former Soviet-bloc countries also come for training.

The first year offers a basic study course on the main topics of the (neo)Protestant doctrine, with evening classes conducted once a week. The second year offers a more solid course in both theology and ministerial practice. The third year is meant for those aiming at full-time ministry and recommended by church leadership.

==Offshoot in Moscow==
On [[March 1]], [[2007]], Hillsong Kiev launched its first service in [[Moscow]], [[Russia]], with subsequent large services, attended both by interested Christians from other churches and  new people, held in April and May. [http://www.risu.org.ua/rus/news/article;16887/] Successfully completing the registration process, in June 2007, the church started holding a weekly service, with an attendance of slightly over 100 as of August 2007. The church plant was cooperatively supported by the Moscow-based Good News Church pastored by [[Rick Renner]]. [http://www.bible.com.ua/news/r/35571], [http://news.invictory.org/issue13083.html]

The church in Moscow is also pastored by Zhenya and Vera Kasevich. They spend part of the week in Kiev and part of the week in Moscow.

==Music==
Hillsong Kiev, as of August 2007, has recorded 16 various albums, including youth and children's albums. Mainly, the songs on the albums are translations of the songs written at Hillsong Australia and, recently, Hillsong London, but there are also original songs written mainly by Vera Kasevich, who also serves as the church's worship pastor, and her and Zhenya's son Roman Kasevich.

The 17th album, recorded live at Hillsong Conference Kiev in 2006, is planned to be released in the fall of 2007.

==Venues==
Hillsong Kiev does not yet own a worship center, renting a public hall in [[Kiev]] downtown for its services. It does own an office, purchased in 2002 with the help of both contributors from the church itself, and supporters abroad. [http://www.hillsong.com.ua/church/venues.html]

==Criticism==
The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.

[[Category:Pentecostal churches]]
[[Category:Hillsong]]
[[Category:Megachurches]]

The criticism of the Hillsong Church Kiev is similar to the criticism expressed with regard to the mother church in Australia (by Australian churches belonging to other denominations) and reflects the general disapproval of certain aspects of what [[Pentecostal|Pentecostals]]/[[Charismatic movement|Charismatics]] believe in from the more traditional Protestant denominations. In particular, the teaching on prosperity is the target of attacks. It must be noted, however, that Hillsong church does not hold the beliefs popularly described as [[Word of Faith|Word-of-Faith movement]], stressing the sovereignty of God and the fulfilling of God's will for the life of each individual believer as the main content of Christian life, which does include hardships and the willingness of the believer to do without. At the same time, the church believes that God does equip the believer with the means necessary for the fulfillment of God's will, a chief part of which is doing good works and helping those in need.

==External links==
* [http://hillsong.com.ua/ Hillsong Church Kiev website], in English and Russian.
